newsitem.title: LATVIA: Latvian banks seek growth in 1997 after crisis.
newsitem.headline: Latvian banks seek growth in 1997 after crisis.

text.p: Banks in the Baltic state of Latvia have made a good recovery after being hit by one of eastern Europe's worst banking crises in mid-1995 and are hoping to make more progress in 1997, bank officials said.
Bank stability has increased and the market is becoming increasingly international as Western banks and those from neighbouring Estonia enter the market.
"The year 1996 was to a large extent a year when authority returned to the banking system," Igor Graur, president of the country's 10th largest bank, Saules Bank, told Reuters.
"In 1997 we should see an increase in the authority of banks," he added.
The crisis was sparked by the closure of the country's largest bank, Banka Baltiya, which caused a loss of deposits for thousands of people and slowed the whole economy.

Latvia's banking sector, like those in most other former Communist bloc states, exploded after it regained independence from Moscow in 1991. The number of banks peaked at 63 in 1993, in a country of 2.6 million people.
Latvia now has 35 banks, though only 14 are allowed to take deposits and they hold some 80 percent of fixed assets in the banking system.
Michael Bourke, an EU PHARE advisor with the central bank, said Latvia has done a lot to get its banking system into shape and now has one of the toughest regulatory systems.
"In 1996 we did at least 110 examinations on site," he told Reuters. "Every site has been been visited, at least once and sometimes three times."
The central bank has introduced rules requiring banks to produce financial information monthly or quarterly and has strict loan-loss provisioning.
"It is safe to say that the banking system is a lot stronger now," Bourke added. "Now we are not just recovering from bad times but we are starting to grow sensibly," Bourke said.
Bankers said that Latvian banks have left the former easy money times behind them and now want to lend sensibly and increase service to their clients.
They are also being pressured by foreign banks as the largest bank in Estonia, Hansapank, has already entered the market.
Latvia also boasts two foreign banks, Vereinsbank and Societe Generale, which have branches.
Saules Bank's Graur said local banks would probably have to merge to reach a size where they can compete beyond Latvia's borders.
His bank has just struck a deal to sell 20 percent of its shares to Tallinna Pank, the fourth largest bank in Estonia.
Unibanka, one of Latvia's largest banks, is in talks with the eighth biggest bank, Zemes Bank.
But Graur was concerned the central bank's tough rules would prevent the growth of Latvian banks by restricting lending too much at a time when credit was needed for an expanding economy.
